body.p: In which of the following scenarios would the distribution of the sample mean x-bar be normally distributed? Check all that apply.

input.choice: We take repeated random samples of size 10 from a population of unknown shape.
We take repeated random samples of size 15 from a population that is normally distributed.
We take repeated random samples of size 50 from a population of unknown shape.
We take repeated random samples of size 25 from a population that of unknown shape.

response.feedback: Incorrect. If sampling from an unknown distribution, the samples size must be larger than 30 for the distribution of x-bar to be normal and n = 10 does not meet this requirement. Also, there is at least one correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that the distribution will be normal despite the small sample size (n = 15) because we are sampling from a normal distribution. However there is at least one more correct answer.
Incorrect. You are correct that the distribution will be normal regardless of population shape because the sample size is large enough (n = 50). However, there is at least one more correct answer.

body.p: When the population is not normally distributed, the sampling distribution of the mean approximates which of the following?

input.choice: A distribution that is not normal
A normal distribution given a large enough sample

response.feedback: Incorrect. The larger the sample size, the closer the sampling distribution of the mean would be to a normal distribution. We can’t automatically assume it will be a normal distribution.
Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest a slight positive skew.
Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest that the distribution is not normal.
Correct. The larger the sample size, the closer the sampling distribution of the mean would be to a normal distribution.
